abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Structural Adjustment Loan in Bulgaria.
            The primary objective of the Structural Adjustment Loan
            (SAL) was to support the Government's economic reform
            program, which aimed to reduce macroeconomic imbalances as
            well as lay the foundation for sustained growth and
            creditworthiness. Despite many shortcomings, the outcome of
            the SAL was satisfactory. The economy was extensively
            liberalized. A basic legal and institutional framework for a
            market economy was established. Implementation of the
            project was satisfactory. The performance of the borrower
            was adequate, especially given the political changes. The
            performance of the Bank was also satisfactory. The SAL was
            approved very early in Bulgaria's political and
            economic transition. Much needed to be done. Market
            institutions and laws did not exist. Thus, it is inevitable
            that some measures supported by the SAL were inappropriate
            to achieve the desired objective or were too ambitious. Most
            measures, however, have yielded important and tangible
            benefits in moving the economy towards one increasingly
            guided by the private sector, while introducing a measure of
            macroeconomic stability. At the same time, project
            sustainability could be at risk, due to the insufficient
            progress on structural reforms (especially privatization,
            public finances and social safety net). Further substantial
            intensification and broadening of structural reforms is,
            therefore, necessary.
